case_name: Legal representatives of Ram Chand Kohli v. State of Uttar Pradesh

facts.text: House No. 11, Kaiserbagh at Lucknow was since 1918 in the occupation of Chowdhry Akbar Hussain.

anchor.surface_text: House No. 11, Kaiserbagh at Lucknow, was since 1918 in the occupation of one Chowdhry Akbar Hussain.

facts.text: Chowdhry Akbar Hussain migrated to Pakistan after the partition of India.

anchor.surface_text: After the partition of India, Chowdhry Akbar Hussain migrated to Pakistan.

facts.text: Deputy Custodian of Evacuee Property, Lucknow declared No. 11, Kaiserbagh as evacuee property by order dated October 12, 1949 under s. 6 of U. P. Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance 1 of 1949 continued by Central Ordinances 12 and 20 of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: By order dated October 12, 1949 the Deputy Custodian of Evacuee Property, Lucknow, in exercise of power under s. 6 of the U. P. Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance 1 of 1949 as continued in force by Central Ordinances 12 and 20 of 1949 declared No. 11, Kaiserbagh as evacuee property.

facts.text: No claim was preferred by any person in pursuance of the notification declaring the property as evacuee property.

anchor.surface_text: No claim was preferred by any person in pursuance of this notification, and management of the property continued with the Custodian of Evacuee Property.

facts.text: Management of the property continued with the Custodian of Evacuee Property.

anchor.surface_text: No claim was preferred by any person in pursuance of this notification, and management of the property continued with the Custodian of Evacuee Property.

facts.text: Central Government acquired the property for the Central pool by notification dated May 27, 1955 under s. 12 of the Displaced Persons Compensation and Rehabilitation Act 44 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Acting under s. 12 of the Displaced Persons Compensation and Rehabilitation Act 44 of 1954, the Central Government by a notification dated May 27, 1955 acquired the property for the Central pool constituted under that Act.

facts.text: The property was put up for sale by public auction on June 7, 1957 and purchased by Ram Chand Kohli.

anchor.surface_text: On June 7, 1957 the property was put up for sale by public auction and was purchased by one Ram Chand Kohli.

facts.text: State of Uttar Pradesh applied under s. 27 of the Administration of Evacuee Property Act 31 of 1950 on September 27, 1961 invoking revisional jurisdiction of Custodian-General against the order notifying the property as evacuee property.

anchor.surface_text: On September 27, 1961 the State of Uttar Pradesh applied under s. 27 of the Administration of Evacuee Property Act 31 of 1950 invoking the revisional jurisdiction of the Custodian-General against the order of the Deputy Custodian notifying the property as evacuee property.

facts.text: State of Uttar Pradesh claimed that the property belonged to the State and Chowdhry Akbar Hussain had no proprietary interest in the property.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Uttar Pradesh claimed that the property belonged to the State and Chowdhry Akbar Hussain had no proprietary interest in the property and accordingly the Deputy Custodian had no power to declare it evacuee property.

facts.text: State of Uttar Pradesh submitted that they were not aware of the notification declaring the property to be evacuee property, subsequent proceedings and sale to Ram Chand Kohli.

anchor.surface_text: It was submitted that the State of Uttar Pradesh was not aware of the notification declaring the property to be evacuee property, not of the subsequent proceedings and of the sale to Ram Chand Kohli.

facts.text: Appellants (legal representatives of Ram Chand Kohli) contended that the petition was belated and property was of ownership of Chowdhry Akbar Hussain lawfully declared evacuee property.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants who are the legal representatives of Ram Chand Kohli contended, inter alia, that the petition was belated, and that in any event the property being of the ownership of Chowdhry Akbar Hussain it was lawfully declared evacuee property.

facts.text: Custodian-General upheld the plea of the State of Uttar Pradesh and set aside the order of the Deputy Custodian by judgment dated September 11, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order, dated the September 11, 1962 of the Custodian General of Evacuee Property... in Revision Petition No. 1209- R UP/1961.

facts.text: Heirs and legal representatives of Ram Chand Kohli appealed to Supreme Court with special leave in Civil Appeal No. 659 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 659 of 1964. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order, dated the September 11, 1962...

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that Custodian-General had jurisdiction under s.27 of Administration of Evacuee Property Act 31 of 1950 to entertain the revision petition.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of the view that the Custodian-General had the power to entertain the revision application filed by the State of Uttar Pradesh.

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside Custodian-General's order due to gross irregularities and breach of rules of natural justice and remands for retrial.

anchor.surface_text: The Custodian-General upheld the plea of the State of Uttar Pradesh, and set aside the order of the Deputy Custodian. With special leave... If the appellants fail... the case must be remanded...

facts.text: U. P. Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance 1 of 1949 was promulgated on June 22, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The U.P. Ordinance 1 of 1949 was promulgated by the Governor of the United Provinces on June 22,1949.

facts.text: Central Ordinance 12 of 1949 was issued by Governor-General before U.P. Ordinance 1 of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Shortly before the promulgation of that Ordinance, the Governor-General had in exercise of the powers conferred by S. 42 of the Government of India Act 1935 issued Central Ordinance 12 of 1949...

facts.text: Ordinance 20 of 1949 issued on August 23, 1949 applied Ordinance 12 of 1949 to United Provinces.

anchor.surface_text: The Governor-General issued on August 23, 1949 Ordinance 20 of 1949, by S. 4 whereof Ordinance 12 of 1949 was applied to the Provinces of Madras and the United Provinces.

facts.text: Custodian-General heard the revision petition on August 4, 1962 and adjourned to August 14, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: The revision petition was heard by the Custodian-General on August 4, 1962, and thereafter the proceeding stood adjourned till August 14, 1962 for further hearing.

facts.text: Appellants' counsel served notice on August 6, 1962 for inspection of documents but no inspection was given.

anchor.surface_text: On August 6, 1962, counsel for the appellants served a notice upon counsel for the State of Uttar Pradesh calling upon him to give inspection of the documents referred to in the notice. No inspection was given...

facts.text: Supreme Court finds procedure by Custodian-General violated natural justice as no opportunity given to appellants to meet new evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The procedure followed by the Custodian-General is in gross violation of the rules of natural justice... without affording to the persons affected thereby an opportunity of meeting that evidence.

issues.text: Whether in a given case, the Custodian-General may entertain a petition against an order passed by a subordinate authority, notwithstanding gross delay in instituting the proceeding, and whether this Court would be justified in interfering under Art. 136 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: powers of the Custodian-General are unquestionably judicial and normally he may not be justified in entertaining a petition in revision which has been instituted after great delay, especially when titles of persons other than those directly concerned in the order sought to be revised, have intervened. There was in this case great delay in lodging the petition by the State of Uttar Pradesh invoking the jurisdiction of the Custodian- General. Whether in a given case, the Custodian- General may entertain a petition against an order passed by a subordinate authority, notwithstanding gross delay

issues.text: whether the Custodian-General had the power to entertain the petition under s. 27 of the Administration of Evacuee Property Act 31 of 1950, challenging the order passed by the Deputy Custodian on October 12, 1949

anchor.surface_text: The question which then must be considered is whether the Custodian-General had the power to entertain the petition under s. 27 of the Administration of Evacuee Property Act 31 of 1950, challenging the order passed by the Deputy Custodian on October 12, 1949. It may at once be observed that the reference in the notification issued by the Deputy Custodian to U.P. Ordinance 1 of 1949 has been made on account of some inadvertence.

issues.text: whether the trial of the petition is vitiated by gross irregularities and breach of the rules of natural justice

arguments.claim: Supreme Court should not interfere under Art. 136 with Custodian-General's discretion to entertain delayed revision.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that in exercise of the appellate jurisdiction of this Court under Art. 136 of the Constitution, we would be justified in interfering with the order of the Custodian-General in a matter which is essentially within his competence and relates to the exercise of his discretion

arguments.claim: Chain of deeming provisions (s.58(3) AEP Act, prior ordinances) does not preserve finality of prior orders to bar revision under s.27 AEP Act 1950.

anchor.surface_text: But it was urged by counsel for the appellants that this chain of fictions did not assist the State of Uttar Pradesh, because by each of the successive statutes the operation of the fiction was subject to the finality of the orders made under the earlier Ordinance.

arguments.court_reasoning: Deeming provisions make prior actions under new Act, subject to its revision powers; finality not overriding; departs from General Clauses Act s.6.

arguments.claim: s.58(3) AEP Act 1950 deems prior actions under Act, subject to its revisional jurisdiction; finality under prior laws does not bar s.27 revision.
Indira Sohanlal and Dafadar Niranjan Singh precedents support that finality under prior laws preserved despite deeming provisions.
arguments.court_reasoning: No support; misinterpretation; chain not broken here; s.58(3) applies fully without qualifying finality.

arguments.claim: Procedure by Custodian-General violated natural justice: acted on new evidence without opportunity to rebut.

arguments.court_reasoning: Set aside due to natural justice violation; remanded for retrial.

holdings.text: The Supreme Court will not interfere under Article 136 of the Constitution with the Custodian-General's exercise of discretion to entertain a revision petition despite gross delay.

anchor.surface_text: We do number think that in exercise of the appellate jurisdiction of this Court under Art. 136 of the Constitution, we would be justified in interfering with the order of the Custodian-General in a matter which is essentially within his companypetence and relates to the exercise of his discretion, however much we may disagree with him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Custodian-General's powers under s.27 are discretionary and judicial; no time limit prescribed; interference under Art.136 justified only in exceptional cases; delay and intervening rights noted but within competence.

holdings.text: The Custodian-General had the power under s.27 of the Administration of Evacuee Property Act 31 of 1950 to entertain the revision petition challenging the Deputy Custodian's order dated October 12, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of the view that the Custodian-General had the power to entertain the revision application filed by the State of Uttar Pradesh.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Chain of deeming provisions in Ordinance 12/1949, Ordinance 27/1949, and s.58(3) of 1950 Act deems prior order as made under 1950 Act, subject to its appellate/revisional jurisdiction; finality under prior laws does not override; departs from s.6 General Clauses Act; distinguishes Indira Sohanlal and Dafadar Niranjan Singh.

holdings.text: The trial of the revision petition by the Custodian-General is vitiated by gross irregularities and breach of rules of natural justice.

anchor.surface_text: If the appellants fail to establish that plea, the case must be remanded to the Custodian-General for retrial, because we are of the view that the trial of the petit-ion is vitiated by gross irregularities and breach of the rules of natural justice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Custodian-General relied on new evidence/documents tendered by State without formal admission order, without giving inspection, opportunity to rebut or lead rejoinder evidence; violates audi alteram partem; Rule 31(9) allows additional evidence discretionarily but requires opportunity.

holdings.text: The order of the Custodian-General dated September 11, 1962 is set aside and the proceedings are remanded for retrial with directions to admit evidence formally and afford opportunity to parties.

anchor.surface_text: In our view the pro- ceedings of the Custodian-General were so wholly inconsistent with the procedure which may be followed in a judicial trial, that his order must be set aside and the proceedings remanded to the Custodian-General with a direction that he do call upon the State of Uttar Pradesh to formally tender in evidence such of the documents on which they rely, and that he do give an opportunity to the appellants in this appeal to tender such evidence as they desire to tender in support of their case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consequence of natural justice violation; specific directions to cure procedural defects.

precedents.case_name: Indira Sohanlal v Custodian of Evacuee Property Delhi & Others
precedents.cited_proposition: scheme underlying section 58(3) is that every matter to which the new Act applies has to be treated as arising under new law except completed acts under old law
precedents.cited_holding: the application for confirmation of exchange was pending on the date Act 31 of 1950 came into force and had to be dealt with under that Act

precedents.citation: Dafadar Niranjan Singh and Another v. Custodian, Evacuee Property Pb. and Another

anchor.surface_text: Dafadar Niranjan Singh and Another v. Custodian, Evacuee Property Pb. and Another 2

precedents.case_name: Dafadar Niranjan Singh v Custodian Evacuee Property Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: chain of fictions broken and finality of order under earlier ordinance preserved preventing revision under s.27 of Act 31 of 1950; s.58(3) fiction subject to finality under old law
precedents.cited_holding: order dated June 6, 1949 could not be deemed under Act 31 of 1950 due to broken chain of fictions

anchor.surface_text: Surtees v. Ellison 1

precedents.cited_proposition: where a statute expires or is repealed, in the absence of a provision to the contrary, it is regarded as having never existed except as to matters and transactions past and closed

anchor.surface_text: In Indira Sohanlars case 3

precedents.case_name: Indira Sohanlal v Custodian of Evacuee Property Delhi & Others
precedents.cited_proposition: application pending when Act 31 of 1950 came into force to be dealt with under the new Act subject to revision

anchor.surface_text: In Dafadar Niranjan Singhs case 1

precedents.case_name: Dafadar Niranjan Singh v Custodian Evacuee Property Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: interpretation of s.58(3): second part subject to first part; if final under old law, fiction does not revive revisional powers
precedents.cited_holding: fiction in second part of s.58(3) operates subject to finality acquired under previous ordinance

anchor.surface_text: Indira Sohanlals case 1 at p. 1133

precedents.case_name: Indira Sohanlal v Custodian of Evacuee Property Delhi & Others
precedents.cited_proposition: saving previous operation of repealed law does not save future operation of previous law

justification_sets.label: Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support
Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support

anchor.surface_text: In our view the proceedings of the Custodian-General were so wholly inconsistent with the procedure which may be followed in a judicial trial, that his order must be set aside and the proceedings remanded to the Custodian-General with a direction that he do call upon the State of Uttar Pradesh to formally tender in evidence such of the documents on which they rely, and that he do give an opportunity to the appellants in this appeal to tender such evidence as they desire to tender in support of their case. Thereafter the Custodian-General shall hear both the parties on the evidence properly brought on the record.

outcome.relief_summary: Custodian-General's order set aside for violation of principles of natural justice; proceedings remanded to Custodian-General for retrial after affording opportunity to both parties to lead evidence
directions: call upon the State of Uttar Pradesh to formally tender in evidence such of the documents on which they rely
give an opportunity to the appellants to tender such evidence as they desire to tender in support of their case
hear both the parties on the evidence properly brought on the record

anchor.surface_text: We do number think that in exercise of the appellate jurisdiction of this Court under Art. 136 of the Constitution, we would be justified in interfering with the order of the Custodian-General in a matter which is essentially within his companypetence and relates to the exercise of his discretion, however much we may disagree with him.

In our view the proceedings of the Custodian-General were so wholly inconsistent with the procedure which may be followed in a judicial trial, that his order must be set aside and the proceedings remanded to the Custodian-General with a direction that he do call upon the State of Uttar Pradesh to formally tender in evidence such of the documents on which they rely, and that he do give an opportunity to the appellants in this appeal to tender such evidence as they desire to tender in support of their case. Thereafter the Custodian-General shall hear both the parties on the evidence properly brought on the record.

edges.explanation: The holding constrains s.58(3) deeming provision to a narrower interpretation where finality is subject to revision under s.27, without rewriting the statute.

Thereafter the Custodian-General shall hear both the parties on the evidence properly brought on the record.
